An older usage means 'to a person possessed by a god, or someone who exhibited intense piety.'

meanings: To mention separately, as in counting.
examples: Can you enumerate the supplies that we will need for the trip?
The teacher enumerated four objectives for the year.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + numerus meaning 'out' + 'number.'
Should not be confused with remunerate meaning 'to pay, recompense, or reward for work, trouble, etc.'

meanings: A particular period of time marked by distinctive features, events, etc.
examples: The popularity of streaming websites and applications marks the end of the epoch of the DVD format.
The Renaissance is an epoch of innovation and transformation.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word epi + echein meaning 'on' + 'to hold.'
Should not be confused with epic meaning 'noting or pertaining to a long poetic composition.'

meanings: Of, relating to, or resembling a horse. (adj.)
A horse. (n.)
examples: There is an ongoing equine flu outbreak in the county during the winter. (adj.)
That is a beautiful equine in your farm. Is it for sale? (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word equus meaning 'horse.'
Equine is for horses, as feline is for cats and canine is for dogs.

meanings: Allowing the possibility of several different meanings, as a word or phrase.
examples: The equivocal statements of politicians often confuse the public.
The instruction was too equivocal; that's why I failed to solve the problem.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word aequus + vocare meaning 'equally' + 'to call.'
The exact opposite of equivocal is unequivocal meaning 'absolute or clear.'

meanings: To go astray in thought or belief.
To make a mistake.
examples: To err is human; to forgive, divine.
I accidentally erred when calculating my tax and had to redo everything.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word errare meaning 'to stray.'
Should not be confused with error which means 'deviation from accuracy or correctness.'

meanings: A short and quick trip to accomplish a specific purpose.
examples: I'm swamped with errands today; I can't rest.
I reduce my errands on weekends by going to the grocery store after work.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word aerende meaning 'message or mission.'
Errand implies 'short and easy task.'

meanings: Deviating from the usual or proper course in conduct or opinion.
examples: She was showing erratic behavior during her shift at work.
Observe if a car is driving in an erratic manner and report to me immediately.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word errare meaning 'to stray or err.'
Erratic implies 'inconsistent and unpredictable.'

meanings: Pertaining to or characteristic of a people, especially a group.
examples: Pupils from a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds study in the school.
The ethnic minority is requesting protection from people encroaching upon their lands.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word ethnos meaning 'nation.'
The related word indigenous means 'born or native to a land or region' while ethnic means 'relating to a group.'

meanings: To show clearly; make evident or manifest.
examples: His letters evince the excitement he felt at winning the trophy.
It was exciting to see children evince an interest in science.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + vincere meaning 'out' + 'to overcome.'
The adjective form evincible which means 'to show clearly' should not be confused with invincible which means 'something which cannot be defeated.'

meanings: To increase the severity, bitterness, or violence of.
examples: Touching a burned skin will exacerbate the pain and infection.
The statement given by the president will exacerbate the tense relationship with other countries.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + acerbus meaning 'out' + 'harsh or bitter.'
In Medicine, exacerbation means 'the worsening of a disease or an increase in its symptoms.'

meanings: To make hollow by removing the inner part.
To dig or scoop out (earth, sand, etc.).
examples: They are planning to excavate a site where ancient potteries were found.
The city government requires a permit if you want to excavate near a busy street.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word cavus meaning 'hollow.'
In archaeology, excavation is the exposure, processing, and recording of archaeological remains.

meanings: To clear, as of an accusation.
To relieve, as from an obligation, duty, or task.
examples: The judge is about to exonerate an innocent man.
He's waiting for his manager to exonerate him from his duties so he can go home early.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + onus meaning 'from' + 'a burden.'
Exonerate is typically used in proceedings with the law.

meanings: Exceeding the bounds of custom, propriety, or reason, especially in amount or extent.
examples: Minnie was surprised at the exorbitant fee from the bank.
I'm trying not to make any exorbitant purchases because of my budget.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + orbita meaning 'out from' + 'course or track.'
Should not be confused with exuberant meaning 'full of vitality.'

meanings: Characterized by promptness.
examples: The assistant provided an expeditious answer to the questions from the managers.
Fast food staff are used to providing expeditious and professional service.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + pes meaning 'out' + 'fetters or chain for feet.'
Expeditious implies 'efficient but careful' whereas hasty implies 'moving in speed or hurried manner.'

meanings: Of great extent.
Covering or extending over a great area.
examples: They are planning to go on an extensive travel around Europe.
The storm covered an extensive area over Scotland.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word ex + tendere meaning 'out' + 'to stretch.'
Extensive may be misspelled as 'extenssive' which is not a word.

meanings: To infer (an unknown) from something that is known.
examples: Data collected from one school cannot be extrapolated to all schools.
The figures were extrapolated from past trends.
further_information: The word was coined in 1862 by combining extra + interpolate meaning 'outside' + 'to introduce (something additional or extraneous) between other things or parts.'
In Mathematics, extrapolate means 'extend (a graph, curve, or range of values) by inferring unknown values from trends in the known data.'

meanings: Spending much more than is necessary or wise.
Exceeding the bounds of reason, as actions, demands, opinions, or passions.
examples: He is known to be an extravagant fellow who spends a lot of money on unnecessary things.
This restaurant is a little too extravagant for my taste.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word extra + vagari meaning 'outside' + 'to wander.'
Extravagant has a more negative connotation than excessive.

meanings: State of being overly excited, joyful and happy.
examples: Jan's exuberance is definitely catching and inspiring.
The wild exuberance of the dancers was loved by the audience.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word uber meaning 'fertile.'
Exuberance is often confused in usage with its adjective form: exuberant.

meanings: Containing falsehood or deception.
examples: Always observe fallacious statements during debates.
The government may be victim to fallacious testimonies.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fallacia meaning 'deceive.'
Fallacious connotes 'intent to deceive.'

meanings: A person with an extreme and uncritical enthusiasm or zeal, as in religion or politics.
examples: Sam considers himself a fitness fanatic and runs every single day.
The posters on your wall show that you're a fanatic supporter of the sports club.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fanum meaning 'temple.'
Fanatic implies 'extreme devotion.'

meanings: Motivated or characterized by an extreme, uncritical enthusiasm or zeal, as in religion or politics.
examples: The fanatical crowd cheered for their candidate.
When Mike was a teenager, he was a fanatical soccer fan.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fanum meaning 'temple.'
Just like its noun form, fanatic, fanatical implies 'extreme devotion.'

meanings: Excessively particular, critical, or demanding.
Requiring or characterized by excessive care or delicacy.
examples: Some children prove to be fastidious eaters, demanding specific food.
His boss is quite fastidious which adds to his worries and stress.
further_information: Evolved from two Latin words fastus + taedium meaning 'contempt or arrogance' + 'aversion or disgust.'
Fastidious implies 'extreme attention to detail.'

meanings: A narrow opening produced by cleavage or separation of parts.
examples: They discovered a fissure on their way down the mountain.
The earthquake created a fissure in the middle of the town.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word findere meaning 'to split.'
A fissure is slightly bigger than a crack.

meanings: Adapted or suited. (adj.)
Fix or put (something) into place. (v.)
A sudden uncontrollable outbreak of intense emotion, laughter, coughing, or other action or activity. (n.)
examples: Jean fits the senior manager position. (adj.)
Wait until the seamstress fits you in a dress. (v.)
She was in fits of laughter after watching the man slip. (n.)
further_information: Observed in the mid-15th century meaning 'suited to the circumstances, proper.'
In Athletics, fit means 'someone who is physically capable.'

meanings: Strikingly bold or brilliant.
Conspicuously dashing and colorful.
examples: His flamboyant performance earned a high score from the judges.
Jimmy loves buying flamboyant cars and motorcycles.
further_information: Originated from the French word flambe meaning 'a flame.'
Flamboyant implies 'something that is noticeable and obvious.'

meanings: A soft, slightly napped fabric of wool or wool and another fiber, used for trousers, jackets, shirts, etc.
examples: He mostly wears flannel pants because of their comfort.
Flannel shirts are usually popular during autumn because of their colors.
further_information: Originated from the Welsh word gwlan meaning 'wool.'
Flannel is a type of cloth usually patterned with black and another color.

meanings: Given or inclined to amorous behavior.
examples: Her flirtatious smile is quite beautiful and endearing.
The guy becomes flirtatious when the girls are around him.
further_information: Originated from the 1500s' word flirt meaning 'joke or jest.'
Flirtatious is sometimes used informally as flirt or flirty.

meanings: A retailer of flowers, ornamental plants, etc.
examples: The florist suggested a bouquet of roses for my girlfriend.
During wedding season, the florist is very busy delivering centerpieces.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word flos + ist meaning 'flower' + 'one who does or makes.'
A florist is usually a business person while a floral designer focuses on design.

meanings: Wave something to attract attention.
To grow luxuriantly, or thrive in growth, as a plant.
examples: The trees we planted last year flourished because of your care.
The waitress served our food with flourish and flash.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word flos meaning 'flower.'
Flourish may also mean 'to succeed or achieve something.'

meanings: Covered with or having many flowers.
(Of speech or writing) Full of elaborate words and phrases.
examples: The garden is flowery this time of the year with roses, tulips, and other beautiful blooms.
She convinced them with flowery words and radiant smile.
further_information: Originated from the 1200s' word flowre + -y meaning 'flower' + 'full of or characterized by.'
Flowery is also a direct synonym of floral.

meanings: The leaves of a plant, collectively.
The representation of leaves, flowers, and branches in paintings, architectural ornaments, etc.
examples: The foliage in the garden is getting too thick. Can you trim it a bit?
The statue is decorated with realistic foliage created by skilled artists.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word folium meaning 'leaf.'
A less popular synonym for foliage is leafage.

meanings: The crime of falsely making or altering a writing by which the legal rights or obligations of another person are apparently affected.
examples: He was falsely accused of forgery by his former boss.
Forgery is considered a felony in most parts of the world.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word forge + ery meaning 'smithy' + 'place for.'
Forgery implies 'a few copied objects' while counterfeit implies 'a large number of copies.'

meanings: Desolate or dreary.
Expressive of hopelessness.
examples: The old house looks very forlorn without the family in it.
I hate leaving every morning because my puppy looks forlorn.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word for + leosan meaning 'completely' + 'to lose.'
Depressed implies heavier emotion than forlorn.

meanings: Going straight to the point.
examples: It is quite a balance to be forthright and polite.
The student was forthright in admitting that he forgot to do his homework.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word forth + right meaning 'forward' + 'morally correct.'
Forthright means 'being straight and honest' while candid implies 'impartial and free from prejudice' and offensive means 'causing resentful displeasure.'

meanings: To protect or strengthen against attack.
examples: The girl was fortified by her faith and managed to cope with her difficulties successfully.
The palace is fortified with stonewalls and wide moats.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word fortis meaning 'strong.'
Fortified can also mean 'to make something better,' as in breakfast cereals fortified with vitamins.

meanings: Characterized by lack of seriousness or sense.
examples: His suggestions were frivolous and were ignored by the team.
Jamie's friend did not believe her frivolous apology and dismissed her.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word frivole meaning 'to rub.'
Frivolous implies 'not having any serious purpose or value' whereas the related word facetious means 'treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.'

meanings: Serving as, or being an essential part of, a foundation or basis. (adj.)
A basic principle, rule, law, or the like, that serves as the groundwork of a system. (n.)
examples: The government is required to protect our fundamental rights. (adj.)
The fundamentals of mathematics include arithmetic. (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Old French word fundare meaning 'to found.'
Fundamentals imply 'building blocks of something more advanced.'

meanings: Incapable of producing any result.
examples: His efforts proved to be futile which frustrated him even more.
All defenses proved futile when the enemy attacked.
further_information: Originated from the Middle French word futilis meaning 'vain or worthless.'
Not to be confused with fertile which means 'productive.'

meanings: Crudely or tastelessly colorful, showy, or elaborate, as with clothes or decoration.
examples: She wore garish clothes and obnoxious jewelry.
They wore silly hats in garish colors.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word gaurr meaning 'rough fellow.'
Not to be confused with garnish which means 'to decorate (especially food).'

meanings: Any article of clothing. (n.)
examples: It is difficult to choose the correct garment to wear for a special party.
I wore a waterproof outer garment in the rain.
further_information: Originated from the Old French word garnir meaning 'equip.'
Garment generally refers to one item of clothing, whereas attire refers to all that one is wearing.

meanings: Shockingly frightful or dreadful.
examples: He had a ghastly look to his face after visiting the horror house.
Jimmy is still sick and that's why he looks ghastly and thin.
further_information: Originated from the Old English word gast meaning 'ghost.'
Terrifying implies a stronger emotion than ghastly.

meanings: An open space in a forest.
examples: The glade is a perfect place to set up camp for the night.
The boy scouts were tasked to find the glade in the forest.
further_information: Originated from the Old Norse word glaðr meaning 'bright.'
Glen is a secluded narrow valley compared to glade which is a clearing.

meanings: Readily fluent, often thoughtlessly, superficially, or insincerely so.
examples: Do not be glib about such a horrible tragedy.
The manager is annoyed by his glib questions and tasteless remarks.
further_information: Originated from the Low German word glibberig meaning 'smooth or slippery.'
Glib may also mean 'being talkative without careful thought.'

meanings: To feed or fill to excess. (v.)
An excessive supply or amount. (n.)
examples: On weekends, I like to glut on ice cream and chocolate chip cookies. (v.)
There is a recent glut of superhero films from popular comic books. (n.)
further_information: Originated from the Latin word glutire meaning 'to swallow.'
A more popular noun is glutton which means 'a person who eats and drinks excessively.'

meanings: To grind or strike (the teeth) together, especially in rage or pain.
To bite with grinding teeth.
examples: The hungry lions gnashed their teeth and lunged at the bars of the enclosure.
He decided to gnash his teeth than say something mean.
further_information: Originated from the Danish word knaske meaning 'crush with the teeth.'
Gnash is different from gnaw which means 'to repeatedly bite something tough.'

meanings: To scoop out or hollow out.
examples: The sculpture was gouged out incorrectly which made the artist very upset.
They tunnel was gouged out of the mountain.
further_information: Originated from the Welsh word gyffin meaning 'beak.'
A gouge is a curved blade while chisel is a flat blade.

meanings: A person charged with the direction or control of an institution, society, etc.
examples: The governor is looking forward to his first official project as a public servant.
A new governor will be elected based on a popular vote next week.
further_information: Originated from the Greek word kybernan meaning 'to steer or pilot a ship.'
The word governor is gender neutral but, sometimes, the word governess is used for a female governor.

meanings: Fond of the company of others.
examples: He is so gregarious that he becomes the life of the party.
A gregarious person usually has many friends and acquaintances.
further_information: Originated from the Latin word grex meaning 'a flock.'
Gregarious implies 'outgoing and comfortable with others' while affable means 'friendly and courteous.'
